definitions.definition: any of the hard white structures in the mouth used for biting food
definitions.labels: (informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: I've just **had a tooth out** at the dentist's.
to **brush/clean your teeth**
**tooth decay**
She answered **through clenched teeth** *(= opening her mouth only a little because of anger)*.
The cat **sank its teeth into** his finger.
She had to have a tooth pulled *(= removed)*.
Billy's first tooth is now through.
Her smile showed crooked teeth.
Her teeth flashed as she smiled.
His pipe was firmly clamped between his teeth.
I lost three teeth in the fight.
I used to be self-conscious of my prominent teeth.
Mink have razor-sharp teeth.
She answered the phone with a cigarette between her teeth.
She wore a brace to correct her gappy teeth.
The cat came in with a mouse in its teeth.
Sugar rots your teeth.
Their teeth were chattering with cold.
Skyscrapers rose like jagged teeth.

definitions.definition: a narrow, pointed part that sticks out of an object

examples.text: the teeth on a saw
The teeth of the cog should fit into these grooves.

definitions.definition: having many weapons
to show your teeth in an aggressive and threatening way

examples.text: The dog bared its teeth and growled.

definitions.definition: if you do something by the skin of your teeth, you only just manage to do it

examples.text: He escaped defeat by the skin of his teeth.

definitions.definition: to do something that gives you your first experience of a particular type of work

examples.text: She cut her teeth on local radio.

definitions.definition: to grow a new tooth
used to say that you should punish somebody by doing to them what they have done to you or to somebody else

examples.text: They advocate a justice system that works on the principle of an eye for an eye.

definitions.definition: to fight in a very determined way for what you want

examples.text: The residents are fighting tooth and nail to stop the new development.
She fought tooth and nail to keep custody of the children.

definitions.definition: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
to put a lot of effort and enthusiasm into something that is difficult enough to keep you interested

examples.text: Choose an essay topic that you can really get your teeth into.

definitions.definition: used when you are saying that you want something very much

examples.text: I'd give my eye teeth to own a car like that.

definitions.definition: to press or hit your teeth together because you feel angry; to feel very angry and upset about something, especially because you cannot get what you want

examples.text: He'll be gnashing his teeth when he hears that we lost the contract.
The news caused great **wailing and gnashing of teeth**.

definitions.definition: to bite your teeth tightly together

examples.text: She gritted her teeth against the pain.
‘Stop it!’ he said through gritted teeth.

definitions.definition: to be determined to continue to do something in a difficult or unpleasant situation

examples.text: It started to rain harder, but we gritted our teeth and carried on.

definitions.definition: to like food that contains a lot of sugar
to be powerful and effective
used to express anger or surprise

examples.text: Hell’s teeth, I promised I’d be back by two.

definitions.definition: despite problems, opposition, etc.

examples.text: The new policy was adopted in the teeth of fierce criticism.

definitions.definition: in the direction that a strong wind is coming from

examples.text: They crossed the bay in the teeth of a howling gale.

definitions.definition: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment

examples.text: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.

definitions.definition: to say something that is not true at all

examples.text: The witness was clearly lying through his teeth.

definitions.definition: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something

examples.text: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

definitions.definition: old or too old
involving opposition or competition that is violent and without sympathy

examples.text: nature, red in tooth and claw

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel physically uncomfortable

examples.text: Just the sound of her voice sets my teeth on edge.

wordOrigin: Old English tōth (plural tēth), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tand and German Zahn, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin dent-, Greek odont-.
